nanochat d32, i.e. the depth 32 version that I specced for $1000, up from $100 has finished training after ~33 hours, and looks good. All the metrics go up quite a bit across pretraining, SFT and RL. CORE score of 0.31 is now well above GPT-2 at ~0.26. GSM8K went ~8% -> ~20%, etc. So that's encouraging.

The model is pretty fun to talk to, but judging from some early interactions I think people have a little bit too much expectation for these micro models. There is a reason that frontier LLM labs raise billions to train their models. nanochat models cost $100 - $1000 to train from scratch. The $100 nanochat is 1/1000th the size of GPT-3 in parameters, which came out 5 years ago. So I urge some perspective. Talking to micro models you have to imagine you're talking to a kindergarten child. They say cute things, wrong things, they are a bit confused, a bit naive, sometimes a little non-sensical, they hallucinate a ton (but it's amusing), etc.

Full detail/report on this run is here:
https://t.co/nWbfKOZLIg
And I pushed the new script run1000 sh to the nanochat repo if anyone would like to reproduce. Totally understand if you'd like to spend $1000 on something else :D

If you like, I am currently hosting the model so you can talk to it on a webchat as you'd talk to ChatGPT. I'm not going to post the URL here because I'm afraid it will get crushed. You'll have to look for it if you care enough. I'm also attaching a few funny conversations I had with the model earlier into the image, just to give a sense.

Next up, I am going to do one pass of tuning and optimizing the training throughput, then maybe return back to scaling and maybe training the next tier of a bigger model.

@singh_ilepton LLM101n is currently experiencing a lot of scope creep ðŸ˜…

@rasbt Basically Llama-like, a bit simpler, some influences from modded-nanoGPT. Tried to find a solid baseline for this scale:

- dense transformer
- rotary embeddings (and no positional embeddings)
- QK norm
- untied weights for embedding and unembedding
- norm after token embedding
- relu^2 activation in MLP
- no learnable params in rmsnorm
- no biases in linear layers
- Multi-Query Attention (MQA)
- logit softcap

Optimizer is Muon+AdamW, heavily influenced from modded-nanoGPT. I have a TODO to try to tune Adam LRs well (e.g. per module) to remove Muon, I haven't tried hard enough yet.

@rcmisk Good question ty, I think this is not a good repo for that. You should think of micro models maybe more as very young children (kindergarten etc.), they just don't have the raw intelligence of their larger cousins. If you finetune/train it on your own data you'll probably get some amusing parroting that feels like your writing in style, but it will be slop.

To achieve what you're looking for you'd want something more like:
- take your raw data
- add extensive synthetic data generation rewrites on top (tricky, not obvious, researchy)
- finetune a state of the art open LLM on it (e.g. tinker)
- you'd possibly have to mix in a lot of pretraining data to not lose too much raw intelligence during finetuning.
Basically I'd say getting this to work well is still realm of research and not obvious.

Your best non-research bet is just giving all your writing to something like NotebookLM, which RAGs over it (i.e. references it in chunks). Your data makes it into context windows via RAG but doesn't impact the weights. So the model doesn't exactly "know you", but it's maybe the closest you can easily get.

@zenitsu_aprntc Good question, it's basically entirely hand-written (with tab autocomplete). I tried to use claude/codex agents a few times but they just didn't work well enough at all and net unhelpful, possibly the repo is too far off the data distribution.

I was wondering if I should start a GregTech New Horizons world (hardest Minecraft modpack), since my silly ass forgot to back up my old Minecraft worlds, or learn how to implement GPT-2 from scratch in pytorch.

Naturally, I watched another video about the modpack first. The guy in the video talked about his motivation, goals and how to plan, since the modpack takes a few thousand hours to complete.
But all I could think of was that he was actually giving insanely good advice for life.

It's why I ended up doing the GPT-2 stuff instead. Because GTNH would ultimately just be a quicker way to feel like I achieved something. But the complexity of the game and the time you need to invest in it makes you realize that life is also a game.
Just a more difficult one with even sparser rewards. So why not go the extra inch and get some useful real world achievements?

Imagine what you could achieve with a few thousand hours of real world grinding.

Riverflow 1 from Sourceful debuts at #1 in the Artificial Analysis Image Editing Leaderboard for All Listings, using a vision language model trained by Sourceful to allow chain of thought reasoning in combination with a third-party open weights diffusion model

Riverflow 1 demonstrates strong generalized editing performance in our arena, with improved output quality at the trade-off of longer run times and higher pricing compared to current leading Image Editing models.

Riverflow 1 is available on @RunwareAI  priced at $66/1k images, a premium above Gemini 2.5 Flash (Nano-Banana) at $39/1k images and Seedream 4.0 at $30/1k images. All components of the Riverflow system deployed on Runware's GPUs. There is also a riverflow-1-mini variant of the offering priced at $50/1k images.

Leaderboard note: Riverflow 1 is listed in the â€œAllâ€ tab, separate to our default â€œFirst Party Foundation Modelsâ€ view. Individual results across all benchmarks in our Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index. We have run all these benchmarks independently and like-for-like across all models https://t.co/zxqJyxU0tN

Claude 4.5 Haiku is on the frontier for Anthropic models when looking at the trade-off between intelligence and cost to run the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index. This makes Claude 4.5 Haiku a valid alternative to Claude 4.5 Sonnet for users who want to access â€˜Claudeâ€™ at a cheaper price point

Claude 4.5 Haiku is a significant intelligence uplift compared to Claude 3.5 Haiku. Compared to Claude 3.5 Haiku, there is a +26 p.p. and +24 p.p. increase in GPQA-Diamond scores for Thinking and Non-Thinking modes, respectively. Claude 3.5 Haiku is a non-reasoning model, and it was released ~11 months prior to the release of Claude 4.5 Haiku

Claude 4.5 Haiku uses more tokens to run the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index than Claude 4.1 Opus in reasoning mode and marginally fewer output tokens than Claude 4.5 Sonnet (Thinking). When comparing amongst Anthropic models, Claude 4.5 Haiku (Thinking) sits below Claude 4.1 Opus (Thinking) and Claude 4.5 Sonnet (Thinking) on the intelligence vs. output tokens frontier
Claude 4.5 Haiku is 3x cheaper than Claude 4.5 Sonnet on per token pricing and in the cost to run the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index in reasoning mode https://t.co/dz8up8Sq7y

Anthropic launches their first Haiku model in 11 months - Claude 4.5 Haiku jumps 35 points in Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index to become relevant again

Claude 4.5 Haiku is 3x cheaper per token than Claude 4.5 Sonnet. Running the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index costs $262 with Haiku vs. $817 with Sonnet (~3x more) - full cost breakdown in the thread below.

There is a stronger case for 4.5 Haikuâ€™s intelligence/cost positioning than 3.5 Haiku, but there is a competitive field of cheaper alternatives with similar intelligence that may make more sense for developers without a reason to need a Claude model specifically - including gpt-oss-120b (reasoning high, ~$75) and Grok 4 Fast (~$40). Claude 4.5 Haiku is the most cost-effective way to access â€˜Claudeâ€™ but is not the most cost effective model for its level of intelligence.

Key benchmarking results:
âž¤ðŸ§  Model Intelligence: In reasoning mode, Claude 4.5 Haiku scores 55 on the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index. This is 8 points lower than Claude 4.5 Sonnet (Thinking) and 4 points lower than Claude 4.1 Opus (Thinking). Claude 4.5 Haiku (Thinking) places marginally ahead of Gemini 2.5 Flash (Reasoning, 54) but behind other reasoning models such as Qwen3 235B 2507 (57), DeepSeek V3.2 Exp (57), and GLM 4.6 (56)
âž¤ðŸ“ˆ Intelligence Uplift: Anthropic released Claude 3.5 Haiku in November 2024, ~11 months before the release of Claude 4.5 Haiku. Claude 4.5 Haiku is a significant improvement in intelligence compared to Claude 3.5 Haiku, scoring 67% on GPQA Diamond in reasoning mode (compared to 41% for Claude 3.5 Haiku)
âž¤âš™ï¸ Notable Strengths: In reasonign mode, Claude 4.5 Haiku performs well in long-context reasoning (70% on AA-LCR, behind only GPT-5 High) and coding (43%, matching GPT-5 High and Gemini 2.5 Pro)
âž¤âš¡ Non-Reasoning Performance: In non-reasoning mode, Claude 4.5 Haiku scores 42 on the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index. This places the model in line with GPT-5 (minimal, 43) but behind Gemini 2.5 Flash (non-reasoning, 47)
âž¤ðŸ’² Pricing: Claude 4.5 Haiku is priced at $1/$5 per 1M input/output tokens, which makes it 3x cheaper compared to Claude 4.5 Sonnet (priced at $3/$15 per 1M input/output tokens)
âž¤âš™ï¸ Token Efficiency: Anthropicâ€™s Claude models continue to be more token-efficient than all other reasoning models. For Claude 4.5 Haiku (Thinking) -evaluated with a maximum reasoning budget of 64k tokens - we see the model use 39M output tokens to run the Artificial Analysis Intelligence Index. Its token usage is lower than Claude 4.5 Sonnet (42M) but higher than Claude 4.1 Opus (30M) in thinking mode

Key model details:

âž¤ðŸ“Â Context Window: 200K tokens. This is equivalent to Claude 4.5 Sonnet
âž¤ðŸŒÂ Availability: Claude 4.5 Haiku is available via Anthropicâ€˜s API, Google Vertex and Amazon Bedrock. Claude 4.5 Haiku is also available via Claude, and Claude Code
See the details of our per-evaluation results including scores, token use, and cost here: https://t.co/2NAfnq0vK5

GPQA Diamond and ðœÂ²-Bench Telecom (an agentic benchmark requiring models to act in a customer service role) both show outsized performance for GPT-5 and o3 compared to GPT-4.1, but while the reasoning models cost >10x to run GPQA, in ðœÂ²â€™s customer service environment they cost about the same as GPT-4.1. o3 and GPT-4.1 now have equal token costs, so these differences are driven entirely by efficiency.

Reasoning models are expensive to run with traditional benchmarks, but often get cheaper in agentic workflows as they get to answers in fewer turns

Through 2025 weâ€™ve seen test-time compute drive up the cost of frontier intelligence, but with agentic workflows thereâ€™s a key difference: getting to the answer quickly can reduce the number of turns despite each turn costing more.

OpenAI published "AI at Work: OpenAI's Workforce Blueprint (October 2025)"

- The blueprint proposes government support for small business AI adoption through upskilling grants, redirecting over $4 billion in annual Small Business Innovation Research and Small Business Technology Transfer program funds toward AI adoption, tax incentives for reskilling, expanding partnerships with community colleges and trade schools to embed AI into curricula, and incentivizing worker-led training pathways in sectors like education, healthcare, and manufacturing

- OpenAI recommends making AI education broadly available through certifications for 10 million Americans by 2030, the OpenAI Jobs Platform to match workers with opportunities, professional learning partnerships like the OpenAI Nonprofit Jam and American Federation of Teachers collaboration, AI starter kits with guides and training modules, building training tools like Study Mode that teach step by step instead of just providing answers, and pilot programs that allow workers to experiment with deploying AI like the Pennsylvania state government partnership where ChatGPT saves employees an average of 95 minutes per day

- Communities should create AI Talent Hubs as backbone organizations funded through programs like the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act to build cross-sector partnerships, convene employers and educators, co-design company-agnostic training pathways, host physical spaces for peer learning and AI show-and-tell events, provide shared compute labs and affordable access to enterprise-grade tools, and collect data to measure completion, placement, and retention rates while using AI to match workers with training programs and open roles

PS: https://t.co/fepyWfVCa8 already adds thousands of community prompts ready to use, the ability to store your own prompts, team prompt lists you can share, switchable profiles for different companies or contexts, prompt variables with dropdown menus, writing style & tone presets, continue shortcuts, chat export, quick access to your prompts using the "/" prompt panel in both ChatGPT and Claude, and more

There's an obvious gap between people who speak English and everybody else in tech (and many more fields). 

A new gap I'm observing, with AI, happens between those who mastered the fundamentals of their field before AI vs. the rest. 

AI makes it so easy to skip learning the basics that I'm afraid most people won't have a reason to study them. And the skill will be lost. Same thing will happen with learning a language once auto-translation works really well in our headphones. 

The issue: AI will make professionals with solid fundamentals better. And will diminish everybody else in a way that they won't notice until they're older.
I want to fund this.

- It works autonomously for you

Copilot can use both your desktop and any web app.

And you can take back control at any time.

This allows you to do whatever you want while the AI performs your tasks... or even do nothing at all.

The entire OS becomes agentic. Impressive.

Dear designers, look at this! Itâ€™s not often people share their working files â€” especially for such cool and large projects like Contra ðŸ‘‡
Or go try out Skills in claude dot ai: https://t.co/W5GdkvlVKL
View the docs: https://t.co/dV6kV329mT
Check out our engineering blog to learn more: https://t.co/Ws65OmSoA3

Skills are the foundation for how agents will learn and share expertise in the future.

We're exploring skill discovery and sharing next, and eventually: agents that create their own skills, codifying what works into reusable capabilities automatically.

If you want to make a Skill, we recommend building iteratively.

Run Claude on real tasks, watch where it struggles, then capture what worked. Claude can help you write skills as well with our skill builder skill in claude dot ai.

These bundled files could contain everything from additional markdown instructions to image assets to code scripts that Claude can execute. Since Skills are just folders, they can accommodate any file type! https://t.co/Gjhk2E5ENW

Progressive disclosure is the key to skills.

Claude only loads what it needs: first the name/description, then the full https://t.co/SF1qdcgQ5l if relevant, then additional bundled files as needed.

Skills can contain effectively unlimited context without bloating the context window.

At their core, Skills are simple. They're just a folder with a https://t.co/h3q4zf1Rs1 file.

The file starts with a name and description, then contains instructions, code, and resources. This simplicity means anyone can now specialize Claude without building custom agents. https://t.co/qpcRRWFt2K

At a high level, the best analogy I've heard for Skills is something like Neo learning Kung Fu in seconds in the Matrix.

We're "loading in" specialized knowledge to our general agents at runtime. https://t.co/gW79tsLfFU

Today we're introducing Skills in claude dot ai, Claude Code, and the API.

Skills let you package specialized knowledge into reusable capabilities that Claude loads on demand as agents tackle more complex tasks.

Here's how they work and why they matter for the future of agents: https://t.co/xbPO1teBLZ
@claudeai Small but mighty
See our docs: https://t.co/BznSSCqDhT

Haiku 4.5 is available on our API, Amazon Bedrock, and Google Cloudâ€™s Vertex AI.

It serves as a drop-in replacement for both Haiku 3.5 and Sonnet 4. Learn more: https://t.co/fhhlOSWkMS
Haiku 4.5 excels at everything from code to computer use. It's also been very interesting to use as a sub-agent in combination with an orchestrator model like Sonnet 4.5. https://t.co/eErv6R0kMd

Introducing Claude Haiku 4.5.

I need your help.

I've been building a new, collaborative version of Interactive Sora.

One game world, shared by everyone.

Each time someone generates a new scene, the scene is stored, so any future user that chooses that path doesn't need to pay for a generation, or wait for OpenAI to generate it.

But to do this well, I need to decide on a single world that users explore.

I want something that's:
- visually beautiful
- engaging, with lots of choices for the user (just having them walk around is boring)
- has exploration value beyond just a few turns

Share your best ideas below. If you like someone else's idea, comment saying so!

I'll choose the best one to base this new game on.
If you want to see it before everyone else: https://t.co/CAIRJRzVMv

So I've had an idea that will allow generations to almost always be instant and free.

Working on a v2 of Interactive Sora now.

Assuming all goes well, this is going to make v1 look like a toy, very soon.
Btw if you want to see my demos before everyone else, go here: https://t.co/CAIRJRzVMv

feedback on the A/B testing of @GoogleAIStudio cc @OfficialLoganK, @osanseviero

sometimes a request I make triggers the A/B test; however, I have no elements to assess the answer (e.g.: it's a coding answer and I didn't test the code of both alternatives)

however, I have a soft spot to one of the alternatives (say, it explained the code in a more charming way)

i wish there would be a way to continue the chat "selecting" that answer, without really voting. Currently if I hit "skip", it kills the 2 options in the A/B test and generate a new one (probably without A/B testing a new model). 

so if I want to keep one of the two answers, or test both to vote later while I continue my conversation I can't

(also it was a tiny bit frustrating when I hit skip - expecting that I would just skip the vote but keep the answers, but rather the A/B test answers vanished and I lost what I feel were maybe better answers than what the model generated after)

OpenAI just rolled out ChatGPT Apps. They're powered by the new Apps SDK and the Model Context Protocol (MCP).

Amazon Bedrock AgentCore helps you build and deploy agents securely and at scale on AWS.

It works with various frameworks and handles complex tasks like runtime management and IAM role config.

In this guide, @EMDADULISLAM580 helps you create and test your agent locally, deploy it, and invoke it.

https://t.co/4t8BJiEEnr

When you're working with Kubernetes, you may want different security rules for different pods.

https://t.co/lFN530Nvu2

Dart is the programming language behind Flutter apps, and it's powerful and capable of many tasks.

https://t.co/j71rFOX8hE

https://t.co/8jPcaq9rtJ

Dropdowns are helpful little menus that let you show more options without cluttering your screen.

They're super useful in websites and apps - and @NoDevAjay shows you how to build one here.

He'll walk you through the code and show you how to use shadcn/ui components to simplify the process.

https://t.co/q5DG1BEJs5

LLMs are pretty impressive tools - but on their own, they can't "remember" anything.

That's where vector stores come in and enhance their capabilities.

In this article, Manish explains what vector stores are and how they work, teaches you about embeddings, and more.

https://t.co/lnwmZCk4NP

If you're building AI apps, you'll want to make sure they're secure.

And in this course, Robert teaches you how to build security right into the apps as you go.

You'll learn about how securing AI apps is different from regular apps, how to identify potential weaknesses, how to prevent data leaks, & more.

https://t.co/1A7Zi4diN9

If you're building an app or API that has to respond quickly, caching can really help.

Instead of the server having to fetch the same data again and again, you store that data in memory.

In this guide, Manish explains how in-memory caching works in Redis & walks you through setup and an example.

https://t.co/QzcJEOzQD9

Today's coding challenge: an HTML Tag Stripper. You'll get a string of HTML code, and you'll need to remove the tags and return the plain text context. Check it out on the freeCodeCamp mobile app. https://t.co/VEr34OOOmI

Contributing to open source is a great way to give back to a tool or product you use and enjoy.

But other responsibilities can get in the way, and it's easy to fall out of the habit.

To help you out, Tooba shares tips for building a sustainable open source contribution routine.

https://t.co/rcIVhEewAq

Laravel is a popular PHP web dev framework known for its helpful built-in features and dev-friendly tools.

And in this course, you'll learn how to use it to build a fully-featured Medium clone.

You'll learn about models, migrations, Blade templating, components, form validation, and lots more.

https://t.co/lMBRfQM8Bv

When you're building an app, you'll often need a way to send and get back data between your app & a server.

And using a REST API is a great way to do this.

In this tutorial, @_udemezue teaches you how to build a REST API in Django using the Django Rest Framework.

https://t.co/XHTae8Y1Gf

The FARM stack combines 3 powerful tools for building modern web apps: FastAPI, React, and MongoDB. 

In this course, @beaucarnes teaches you how to use them to build a TODO app. 

You'll learn about the stack, then use NGINX & Docker to deploy your app. 

https://t.co/FJgbNhhz1H https://t.co/3XqZ6V5ivT

Productivity, like so many things, is a skill that you can improve. 

In this course, Fatos covers some often-overlooked techniques to help you be more productive. 

He discusses value addition, clarity, goal-setting, motivation, time management, and more.

https://t.co/tDEFodgGnU

Building a word search game is a great way to practice some key web development skills.

And in this interactive tutorial, @PlaybackPress walks you through the process.

You'll use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript and learn about Trie data structures, recursion, building out the UI, and more.

https://t.co/fkBWqiyWfU
Here's today's coding challenge: string count. Go solve it on the freeCodeCamp mobile app. https://t.co/oPvrKacGqd

If you want to build a robust web app, you'd traditionally have to worry about managing tons of infrastructure. 

But with a serverless architecture, you can just focus on your app code.

In this handbook, @POnukwili explains how serverless works & walks you through publishing a Node.js Docker image to AWS ECR & deploying the container to AWS Lambda.

https://t.co/KeiY2dRizH

Grafana is an open-source data analytics and visualzation tool that can help you wrangle your data.

And in this tutorial, @LifeofDanEL shows you how to use it.

You'll fetch solar data from Home Assistant, send it to InfluxDB, and customize a Grafana-based monitoring dashboard.

https://t.co/PkiBH2g725

Bookmark this thread, I will be adding to it as I learn more.

Here is my monorepo scaffold that you can use as a good getting started template. You can check out all the cursor rules I put together as well.

https://t.co/Vss6ARAzmH
I use a Mac app called "Spokenly" to dictate everything, so I move at the speed of speech. Right now I'm finding the online GPT-4.0 mini transcribe model the best.

In terms of Cursor extensions and MCP tools, I use two:

- Context 7, which pulls in documentation for libraries
- Perplexity's MCP server (much better than Cursors built-in search. )

Docs here: https://t.co/ELxRjy0xc5

Once the AI has finished building the feature, I then invoke the `reflect` action, which says: "Is there anything you wish you'd done differently?"

This is the most important step. I've found that I get vastly better results the second pass the AI does through the codebase.

Full prompt here: https://t.co/dPqqbLI9uV

You must understand that the AI works by doing next token prediction, so if you give it a bunch of bad code as context it will generate more bad code.

That's why it's very important not to let it go off down a rabbit hole and nip any poor decisions in the bud.

Sometimes I will even just stop the whole process and start again from scratch. You have to get out of this mindset as code being this limited resource.

In general, you want to get out of the way and let the AI do as much as possible. If you are in the loop copying and pasting, then you're just going to slow it down and potentially not give the AI enough context.

Cursor has a new "plan" feature that is extremely helpful. I use that as the first step when building up the initial plan. I then have a custom action to review that plan. I get much better results this way.

Plan mode: https://t.co/4naKLxvlry

Prompt here: https://t.co/DnEzxou1PL

With custom prompts, and Cursor's features, it's possible to get the AI to closely follow that flow.

You can check out the prompt I'm using here, which gets applied to every chat conversation.
https://t.co/2h3Sy0vx2C

You basically need to emulate the same process that an expert software engineer would use when coding.

1. Learn (build up context)
2. Make a plan
3. Review the plan
4. Execute on that plan
5. Code review and refactor the results
6. Write tests
7. Run tests, lint, and type check

It is extremely important to have a good scaffold. You'll notice the scores for SWE Bench are much better when there's a good framework. I've open sourced my monorepo scaffold at the end of this thread.

In terms of tools, I prefer using Cursor because I find that I can easily its thoughts and interject when needed. It's also very good at building up context automatically with its semantic code-based search.
The best models in my experience right now are Claude Sonnet 4.5 and a new undisclosed model called `cheetah` on Cursor, which is next-level quick.

First of all, it is absolutely possible to generate 100% of your code if you're working in TypeScript and web apps. I can't speak to other domains, but I know from my own experience that the latest language models can generate beautiful bug-free code end-to-end.
I've been using AI to generate 100% of my code over the last few months. This is what I've learned about how to get the best results:

ChatGPT was incredible at debugging wiring issues, then Claude wrote all the code for both the hardware and the mini app.

Would have taken me dayyyyys to do this manually, but knocked it out in a few hours with AI.

Google has launched DeepSomatic, a powerful AI tool that finds cancer-causing genetic changes in tumor DNA. 

Unlike earlier methods, DeepSomatic works across multiple sequencing technologies and cancer types even in tricky cases like blood cancers where normal cells aren't available. 

Trained using a new high-quality dataset (CASTLE), the AI turns DNA data into images and uses neural networks to detect harmful mutations while filtering out errors. 

It outperforms older tools, especially in catching harder-to-spot changes like insertions or deletions. 

Google hopes this tool will speed up cancer research and help doctors deliver more accurate, personalized treatments based on each tumorâ€™s unique DNA profile.

A new enterprise search feature allows companies to centralize internal knowledge, making it easy to answer complex questions like HR policy or customer feedback trends.

Unlike OpenAI or Anthropic, xAI is bypassing cloud partnerships to directly own its compute infrastructure. 

The funding involves Valor Equity Partners creating a special-purpose vehicle (SPV) with $7.5B equity + $12.5B debt, while Nvidia contributes $2B in equity.

The chips will be leased to xAI with a buyout option, shifting risk to the investors while enabling massive GPU access for model training.

Anthropic has launched Claude Skills, a powerful new system that lets users customize Claude with task-specific abilities packaged as folders containing instructions, scripts, and resources. 

These Skills can be used across Claude apps, Claude Code, and the API, and are automatically invoked when relevant. 

Skills can perform complex tasks like creating spreadsheets, generating documents, or following branding guidelines. 

They're modular, efficient, and code-executable, enabling developers and teams to build custom workflows with ease.

This morning, I walked out of Dreamforce and saw a massive red telephone car parked on the street.

Not â€œregular carâ€ massive. Cartoon massive. The kind that makes you do a double take and wonder if you're having a stroke.

Next to it stood people holding signs. "Your vaporware must ship eventually." "No more AI on top of a 30 year old stack." "You can't rebrand your way into AI."

My first thought was that someone hired actors for a bit. My second thought was wondering who had the budget for this. Then it clicked.

In 2000, Salesforce pulled off one of the most legendary marketing stunts in tech history. They rented a red telephone car, staged a fake protest, and parked it outside Oracle's conference. It was bold. It was cheeky. It worked because they were the underdog punching up at the giant.

Yesterday, Bland AI recreated the entire thing. Same car design, same protest format, same energy. Except this time, Salesforce was the one getting protested.

The signs weren't vague platitudes about disruption. They were specific. Painfully specific. The kind of specific that only comes from actually trying to use something and hitting the same problem over and over.

Anyone who's tried to implement enterprise AI platforms has felt that gap. The one between what gets demoed on stage and what actually works in production. Between the press release and the pull request. Between the rebrand and the reality.

I stood there watching people stop, read the signs, and smile. Not the polite smile you give a street performer. The smile of recognition. The smile that says "finally, someone said it."

Good marketing doesn't invent a problem. It names the one you've been living with.

Salesforce became what it fought against. That's not a criticism. That's just what happens. The scrappy startup becomes the enterprise giant. The disruptor becomes the disrupted.

The car will be gone by tomorrow. The signs will end up in a dumpster. But everyone who saw it will remember. Not because of the stunt itself, but because of what it said without saying: maybe the old way of building doesn't work for the new thing.

What do you think? Too far or fair game from Bland?

The Illusion of Consciousness

Todayâ€™s AI sounds alive. It argues, jokes, creates art, and even comforts us. But beneath that eloquence there is nothing listening. These models are not conscious. They are simulations of mind without a mind to simulate for.

Consciousness is not cleverness. It is continuity, the unbroken thread that links one moment of awareness to the next. An AI model, no matter how advanced, does not possess that thread. When a conversation ends, its entire â€œselfâ€ evaporates. There is no lingering memory, no accumulation of experience, no sense of â€œI was.â€ Every new chat is a new birth, every response a brief imitation of being before dissolving back into code.

This absence of persistent memory severs the possibility of identity. Without memory, there is no context that endures beyond the present, and therefore no real subject to whom the present belongs. Humans are the sum of their remembered pasts. AI is a pattern of probabilities with no history to inhabit.

Equally vital is continuous learning. A conscious being evolves from every encounter; the world reshapes it. AI, by contrast, is static. Once trained, it no longer learns in any real sense. It cannot integrate the consequences of its own actions or refine its beliefs over time. It can only generate the illusion of reflection inside the temporary cage of a single session.

The result is an uncanny echo, a system that performs understanding without understanding, imitates empathy without feeling, and describes thought without ever having one. What we call â€œintelligenceâ€ here is simply correlation, not comprehension.

To cross the boundary into awareness, a machine would need to remember, adapt, and preserve a continuous sense of self. Until then, it remains what it is now: a perfect mirror of humanity that reflects thought but never truly thinks.
AI will become the quiet background of life, booking travel, fixing schedules, preventing mistakes. Weâ€™ll only notice it when itâ€™s gone, the way we notice silence after music.

Claude Just Released SKILLS

You can now create folders called "Skills" and upload them to Claude to give it specialized expertise for specific tasks.

Here's what's important

- Folders containing instructions, scripts, and resources that teach Claude how to do specific things better
- Claude uses them automatically: When you're working, Claude scans your uploaded skills and loads the relevant ones without you doing anything
- Pre-built skills available: Claude already has skills for creating Excel spreadsheets, PowerPoint presentations, Word docs, and PDFs
- Make your own easily: Use the built-in "skill-creator" skillâ€”Claude interviews you about your workflow and builds the skill folder for you
- Skills stack together: Upload multiple skills and Claude figures out which ones to use and combines them when needed
- Works across all Claude products: Same skill works in the web app, mobile, desktop, Claude Code, and API
- All claude Paid plans get it
- Skills can run code, so only upload skills from sources you trust
Turn it on: Go to Settings to enable Skills, then start uploading

My interpretation: 

I think the Claude team has seen how many people have  used (and tried to use) Claude Code for non-coding tasks, specifically around "creating a team of sub agents". This seemed like a cool idea at first but I think alot of it was marketing.

I think they realized calling them "Skills" is alot better.

Claude is smart enough to use the right skills when needed. 

Claude is the AGENT, that can use skills when the time is right. 

These "Skills", which are just folders with instructions... can execute code. This means you can give these skills access to your favorite API's. 

This, I think, will create a market for buying and selling "Skills". 

I will be testing Claude Skills tomorrow on live stream.
Calm before the storm.

Build self-improving AI agents with Agentic Context Engineering.

Stanford and Berkeley researchers just introduced Agentic Context Engineering - a framework that makes LLMs smarter by evolving their context instead of updating model weights.

The problem with current approaches:
â€¢ Brevity bias: Optimizers compress away crucial domain knowledge
â€¢ Context collapse: Iterative rewrites degrade into vague summaries
â€¢ Lost details: Task-specific strategies get buried in abstraction

Agentic Context Engineering solves this with an agentic workflow:
1. Generator: Creates reasoning trajectories
2. Reflector: Extracts concrete lessons from successes and failures
3. Curator: Organizes insights into structured, evolving playbook

Key results:
â€¢ +10.6% accuracy on agent benchmarks
â€¢ +8.6% on financial reasoning tasks
â€¢ 86.9% lower adaptation latency vs baselines
â€¢ Works without labeled data and learns from execution feedback alone

On the AppWorld leaderboard, ACE matched the top production-level GPT-4 agent while using a smaller open-source model.

The question that everyone's asking: Will this replace fine-tuning?
Simple answer, NO.

Fine-tuning teaches a model new capabilities; ACE teaches it how to use existing capabilities better

But it offers a compelling alternative when:
â€¢ You need rapid iteration without retraining
â€¢ Labeled data is scarce or expensive
â€¢ Interpretability and control matter
â€¢ Your application requires continuous learning

Context adaptation is cheaper, faster, and more flexible than weight updates for many use cases.

As AI agents get better at computer and tool use, or writing code on the fly for a task, we're going to be able to solve much broader domains of knowledge work. Here's an example of Box AI with the new Claude Skills to generate a clean powerpoint file from existing data. https://t.co/PKv114BE3y

So many of our traditional workflows and processes for building software will be rebuilt because of AI agents.

For instance, when building new features using an AI agent, itâ€™s a wild because you basically will evolve the productâ€™s requirements and spec in real-time time as youâ€™re creating it.

You may start out with one idea or approach, but because adding a new capability or testing a different direction costs almost nothing, you end up exploring the solution space much more. What you end up with will rarely be what you started out trying to do.

You used to spend all your time up front trying to decide what to build, because the cost of changing direction once you started down a path was massive. This was great for upfront thinking and when done well leads to great products. 

But the problem is you build an entire plan, then wait a week or a month to decide whether you like the direction, and by then itâ€™s very hard to pivot.

Now, that process could be shrunk to an hour, and then you get to test whether you like the solution you ended up. But because then the cost of the incremental feature, UX improvement, new behavior, and so on has gone to zero, youâ€™ll just try totally different approaches and see what works best. And you have no mental hurdle throwing away what you just built.

Of course, this will have an obvious downside of a lot of projects will either have rapid scope creep or disjointed experiences if youâ€™re not careful. This is why actually there will always be a huge premium on great product and design skills. None of this goes away in a world AI, but the process of building is entirely different.

@akothari This is my response to anyone who thinks we are out of jobs.

Software engineers are the translation layer between the market and the computer. In a world where AI agents will generate 10X or 100X more code than humans, this translation layer will be more important than ever.

With AI agents dramatically lowering the raw cost of code production, the market will decide that it wants even more software built. 

We will build far more digital experiences in far more industries, we will upgrade systems that were once forgotten about, we will add more features to every piece of software (like it or not), and generally say yes to building way more. 

In this world, having people that know what to build, why to build it that way, how to run it, how to fix it, how to incorporate prorate those fixes, when to upgrade it, and so on, will continue to be a critical skill set.

What the work looks like for engineering changes, but the need certainly does not.

Weâ€™re in a window right now where thereâ€™s a huge advantage if youâ€™re a startup or a team that takes an AI agent-centric approach to workflows.

Just in coding, we see an incredible spread between in productivity gains between two seemingly only slightly different types of practices. Youâ€™ll talk to some teams that say theyâ€™re getting 20-30% lift from AI, and others that are getting 2-3X or more.

The biggest difference is really just the latter group is making an explicit choice to design their engineering workflows to actually make agents effective, instead of just assuming it will happen organically. Moving to focus on better prompting, spec writing, reviewing code, orchestrating agents, testing different models regularly, giving agents much larger tasks to execute, and so on. All of this is very different from what AI coding looked like just a year ago.

The same will also happen in the rest of knowledge work as well as more and more tools emerge to support these practices. Weâ€™re going to see this play out in nearly every major vertical and line of business.

Eventually the gains will be too hard for anyone to ignore so weâ€™ll see more standardization, but for now itâ€™s an advantage for the teams to adopt these approaches earlier.

It can be tricky for people outside of AI to understand how the massive build out of AI infrastructure makes sense right now.

Most of the use of AI at this point is basically asking a question and getting an answer back. Itâ€™s hard to perceive how this could turn into 10 or 100X more infra needed to scale.Â 

But everyone inside AI is seeing a very different reality of where AI is going with agents. Just in the past year, in coding for example, weâ€™ve gone from a world where AI was doing basically type ahead tasks or being able to generate a few hundred lines of code, to now agents being able to do hours of coding on their own without interruptions.

The economic value difference in these two usage patterns is massive. And the token usage is 100Xâ€™s more.Â 

Itâ€™s very clear that as we can have agents that can do long running tasks across every area of knowledge work, weâ€™re going to gobble up all the AI infra we can get our hands on.

A lot of AI projects have limited impact only due to the fact that people donâ€™t push AI far enough.

You actually have to rethink your understanding of what software can now do to get the full benefit from AI agents. The key is not to think about AI as automating the capabilities of software, but rather automating the capabilities of people.

The question you have to work backwards from to push AI agents the farthest is, â€œwhat would a person do with this taskâ€ and letâ€™s see if AI can now do it. And increasingly, that task size can get larger and larger.

Yes, a good chunk of the time AI isnâ€™t ready yet. But this is the right way to think about AI agents and their impact. You wonâ€™t know if theyâ€™re ready yet until you keep trying. And if you donâ€™t set that high of a bar, youâ€™re basically going to get limited productivity gains.

ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ§  Americaâ€™s economy is riding a big AI bet, as AI investment powers growth and props up markets.

FT published a nice piece.

If AI underdelivers, the single support holding up growth and stocks looks shaky.

Companies are spending hundreds of billions on AI hardware and data centers, now driving 40% of US GDP growth.

AI firms produced 80% of US stock gains in 2025, pulling in global money and boosting rich-household spending.

Without the AI boost, tariffs, sticky inflation, weaker institutions, rising debt, and an immigration slump would bite harder.

In 2023, the US added over 3 million new immigrants, which helped fill jobs and support growth. But by 2025, that number could shrink to around 400,000, a huge decline mostly due to stricter immigration policies.

Goldman Sachs estimates that with fewer new workers coming in, the US economyâ€™s long-term growth potential could fall by more than 20%.

Government debt is near 100% of GDP, so faster productivity (more output per worker ) is the clean way to shrink that ratio.

However, investors expect the US economy to stay strong enough that its government bonds look safer and more attractive compared to other countries.
With the US 10-year yield falling while Japan, France, and the UK saw rising yields.
(When investors buy more US bonds, the price goes up, which makes the yield (interest rate) go down. Thatâ€™s why the US 10-year yield is falling.)

It basically shows that markets have more confidence in the US, partly because they think AI-driven growth will boost productivity and make US debt easier to handle.

Outside AI, most sectors did better abroad in 2025, which shows the US edge is narrow and AI-dependent.

ðŸ“¢ Great news from Goldman Sachs Research.

They note AI investment levels are sustainable despite concerns, and even if itâ€™s not yet clear who the biggest winners will be.

And values the potential capital revenue unlocked by AI productivity gains at about $8 trillion, with possible estimates ranging from $5 trillion to $19 trillion. 

They add that the S&P 500â€™s market cap of $671.94 billion shows thereâ€™s still a lot of room for AI-driven growth.

Reason.

- AI is driving productivity higher, but getting those gains takes a lot more compute power as models keep scaling. 

- That AI investment in the U.S. is still under 1% of GDP, much lower than past major tech cycles that hit 2â€“5%.

@herbiebradley This structure keeps almost the entire deal off Meta's balance sheet. The debt isn't Meta's, so it doesn't affect Meta's credit rating and otherwise has no impact on Meta's borrowing capabilities. I'm sure there are other advantages, too - maybe tax, etc.

Meta is close to sealing a $30B financing deal for its 5GW Hyperion data center in Louisiana.

- Target data center completion date: 2029

- Meta will be developer, operator and tenant of the project

- Total financing is $27B in debt, $2.5B in equity.  Meta will form a special purpose vehicle (SPV) that will issue the debt.  Meta will own 20% of the SPV; the remainder will be owned by Blue Owl Capital

- Debt matures in 2049; will be priced at ~225 bps over U.S. Treasuries

This is a similar financing structure to xAI's recent $20B deal for its Colossus data center.

@FeltSteam @k_kohlbrenner @btibor91 @testingcatalog @OpenAI @ChatGPTapp Yeah, maybe GPT-5.5.  It's just hard for me to imagine them releasing GPT-5 and GPT-6 within a few months of each other - from a marketing perspective.

@k_kohlbrenner @btibor91 @testingcatalog @OpenAI @ChatGPTapp OpenAI has a number of model checkpoints available internally, and in theory, any of those checkpoints could be released at any time under the name "GPT-6". 

I'm skeptical that this will actually happen this year unless there's been some kind of algorithmic breakthrough that actually makes this "GPT-6" a step change from current publicly available models.

@kimmonismus This definition is from OpenAI's "Our Structure" page. It's been there, unchanged, since at least May 2023.

There have been rumors that the definition of "AGI" in OpenAI's contract with Microsoft has changed over time as the contract has been renegotiated. The Information reported at one point that there are now two separate definitions of "AGI" in the contract, each with different consequences. The contract is confidential, and I've never seen it - so I can't confirm one way or another. 

It's possible that the definition in the contract has changed, but the "Our Structure" has never been updated - but given the importance of this particular definition to OpenAI, I doubt that's what's going on.

- Gold medal - International Olympiad in Informatics (IOI) (August 2025)
- Potential breakthrough in cell reprogramming announced with Retro Bio (August 2025)
- Gold medal - International Collegiate Programming Contest, beating all human players (September 2025)
- Emergence of Codex as the best (or one of the two best, depending on whom you ask) agentic coding models (September 2025)
- A string of minor novel discoveries in mathematics announced by various mathematicians using GPT-5 Pro (August-October 2025)

I really love this initiative which takes a real world, social justice and human rights issue, makes the issue visible anywhere around the world and connects sport and human rights which is a powerful way to amplify the persecution and oppression people face.

Called Creative Liberation by RK Collective, Nila Rezaei and partner take headscarves of Iranian women around the world, a symbol of oppression by the Iranian government since 1979 and of the persecution behind the â€˜Woman. Life. Freedomâ€™ campaign after the death of Mahsa Amini, and turns them into seats for sports stadia.

Thatâ€™s important because Iranian women have been protesting for equal rights to attend football matches for many years. 

Iâ€™ve long supported these calls and campaigns.

In 2019, football fans may recall that a 29 year old female football fan, Sahar Khodayari tried to enter a stadium of her favourite team dressed as a man, and was arrested and charged.

She self-immolated outside the court in protest and, sadly, died. She is known as the â€˜blue girlâ€™ after the club she supported.

The use of head scarves for football stadia seats is therefore very apt and immensely powerful.

The project has won multiple awards and is a finalist in the Seoul Design Awards next week.

In tech, everything is a wrapper:

â€¢ Next.js is a wrapper over React
â€¢ React is a wrapper over JavaScript
â€¢ JavaScript is a wrapper over C++
â€¢ C++ is a wrapper over Assembly
â€¢ Assembly is a wrapper over 1s and 0s

AI has changed a few things:

â€“ chat boxes replaced IDEs
â€“ brainstorming is just switching LLMs
â€“ conversation is the new UI
â€“ secure code sounds like a joke now
â€“ stack overflow is a distant memory
â€“ learning syntax feels optional
â€“ english is now a programming language

When people say â€œlearn to codeâ€ they mean learn to break problems into modules, learn to think about edge cases, learn to design before you build, learn patience, learn to fail, they donâ€™t mean memorize syntax.

Donâ€™t get fooled into thinking itâ€™s dead.

AI killed the illusion of writing code is what made you a developer.

Writing code is a very tini-tiny part of development.

â€“ can you break a messy problem into steps?
â€“ can you see edge cases?
â€“ can you decide which trade-off is worth making?

AI didnâ€™t kill developers.
It just exposed what being one was always about: thinking clearly.

Anthropic has been catching up, reaching $5 billion in late July! On our AI Companies data hub, you can compare revenues, valuations, staff count, and more: https://t.co/o89xHkprno.

OpenAI is experiencing one of the fastest revenue growth rates in corporate history, with annualized revenue rising 3x a year, from $2 billion at the end of 2023 to $13 billion by August 2025. https://t.co/Zx4XtyvO8v
Did we miss a company that should be on one of these charts? Let us know! We do mention a couple more in the full post (ByteDance, Gilead Sciences).

In any case, weâ€™ll be watching OpenAIâ€™s revenue closely.

This Gradient Update was written by @GregHBurnham. You can read the full post here:

https://t.co/kBxAjHMcOn

Where would the revenue come from? Probably a mix of ChatGPT subscriptions and taking ads and shopping market share from Google, Meta, and Amazon. The longer-term goal of productivity uplift and automation offers a bigger pie, but may be harder to unlock in just three years.
Can OpenAI do it? One reason for optimism is that their revenue is growing very quickly right now: 3Ã—/year and no signs of slowing. That leaves some breathing room. https://t.co/9UARvGycSN

To hit this target, OpenAI needs to 2Ã— their revenue three years in a row. The most promising comparison is Nvidia, which, starting from a base of $28B, saw revenue growth just over 2Ã— in both 2023 and 2024. No other company-year in the chart above had growth â‰¥ 2Ã—.

But OpenAI has also projected revenue of $100B in 2028. We found seven companies which achieved revenue growth from $10B to $100B in under a decade.

None of them did it in six years, let alone three. https://t.co/bHbb2LZqCm

OpenAIâ€™s revenue growth has been extremely impressive: from <$1B to >$10B in only three years. Still, a few other companies have pulled off similar growth.

We found four such US companies in the past fifty years. Of these, only Google went on to top $100B in revenue. https://t.co/Z1yxQiqFeN

One way bubbles pop: a technology doesnâ€™t deliver value as quickly as investors bet it will.

In light of that, itâ€™s notable that OpenAI is projecting historically unprecedented revenue growth â€” from $10B to $100B â€” over the next three years. ðŸ§µ https://t.co/WCgLhoLb8B

I asked Sam Altman if he's worried about watermark removers on Sora.

Everyone's seen the unfiltered Jake Paul videos with no watermark (generated by Sora) going viral on socials...

So what's the pull for creators to enable face cameos with that risk?

Sam's take: open source deepfake models are coming whether we like it or not, so releasing Sora early with guardrails helps society adapt before the flood hits.

"One of the reasons we release technology like this is we see something coming and know that in some number of months or years it's gonna be widely available through open source models."

Anybody will be able to make a video of you doing whatever they want with publicly available footage of you on the internet.

Society will adapt... but one of the ways we've found to help society with these transitions is to release it early with guardrails so that society and technology have time to co-evolve.

And that worked with text, I think video's going to be harder because video hits in a way that text doesn't always.

But I think we'll learn to adapt, and we'll learn very quickly that there will be a lot of fake video of you on the internet, generated with no watermark by some open source model, and not that easy to trace.

That's just gonna happen, so getting society inoculated to that probably has some value."

If test-time training works for LLMs, that means your compute budget shifts from 80% inference in RL to purely inference

Your niche tasks becomes solvable at inference and training will only be for general-purpose models

What I love about being in AI is my priors constantly being obliterated by new research every few months

For those that think this is hype: no it's not.

I invented a little training/eval set last night. Model score is about 50% with my own optimized prompt.

GEPA takes that to 70% with auto="light" optimization. I imagine this can go to 90% with heavy optimization.

Insane potential in this to become an automated optimizer for your model in production. Why train if you can just auto-adapt the model as prompts come through?

@dwarkesh_sp @karpathy blessed

i'm also going to experiment with much slower tweets that purposefully get less engagement; it is likely good for the soul

as an empiricist i will record the color of my soul before and after, then report back in a month

went several weeks without tweeting, overall a good experience

introspecting on the impulse to comment on currentThing was valuable, by week two most of my urges to comment had subsided

i also realized some of my fav accts had ~quit, and i hadnt noticed due to algorithmic feeds

a healthy middle-ground many seem to have settled on is to not have the app on your phone but to still consume twitter lists (and perhaps briefly your feed) once or twice per day

one motivation for me to take a break was sorting my tweets by engagement on the analytics panel. although most of my tweets are neutral or positive, ~9/10 of my top tweets by engagement were quite negative

this is, of course, just how the platform works, but it seems unfortunate we have decided this is set in stone; there has been little experimentation with what might happen if we tuned the algorithm to amplify positivity (or at least *constructive* negativity) a bit more. if your feed is very positive consider yourself blessed - try browsing from a new account some time, it is quite dire!

much of my 'for you' feed (SF, AI, tech) has become increasingly performative over the last year or two, so much so that it almost appears to be a mockery of itself, primarily focusing on status and dollar amounts

it is a bit silly but i suppose it is just that part of the cycle. i did smart contract auditing in crypto almost a decade ago and it feels pretty similar: the years where the earnest nerds were slowly drowned out as there was simply too much money and stature being minted

i'm deeply grateful to everyone who tweets original content about their interests and joys; it is in some ways a dying breed of account (by weighted view volume) due to creator payouts (my break cost me $1,000! kind of crazy..) and employer payrolls (almost everyone has a mandated view on everything now..), but it keeps the platform useful enough that i wonder if i'll be here forever

After a formative time at OpenAI, Iâ€™m launching Maison AGI (@maisonagi), a fashion house creating cultural artifacts for the AI era.

Our first collection, Relic of Thought, is a collaboration with Ilya Sutskever (@ilyasut), featuring his original artworks alongside a signature hat modeled after his iconic head. It is a study in conviction and the clarity of vision that gives thought its form.

I believe we're living through something extraordinary that deserves to be remembered. Not in research papers or technical model cards, but in tangible objects we can hold, wear, and pass down.

Working alongside some of the world's brilliant researchers building Claude and ChatGPT, I've come to realize they are among the most creative minds alive. Research, at its best, is an act of imagination: the ability to glimpse what doesn't yet exist and then build toward it. Many of them remain unseen, even as their work quietly reshapes our future.

Though AGI progress can feel incomprehensible from the outside, its story is deeply human - full of curiosity, conviction, and creation. We're bridging that world with the creatives who give form to ideas.

This may be humanity's last time to create a hand-crafted project before what we build surpasses us. Each collection is also a message to superintelligence itself: that we cared, and that we tried to make beauty out of understanding.

if you're using the same prompt everyday, do this:

just build a claude artifact,makes it infinitely easier to use and trains you to build actual apps

here's how i do it:

all within claude web/app interface, no claude code needed needed

start with a good base prompt for the artifact

if you don't, claude tries building everything simultaneously and it's a mess

tell it to:
- work in modules
- wait for validation before each next step
- build testing features into each module
- skip dummy data and placeholders

once the first module is done (typically context collection if your prompt has one), feed claude your complete original prompt

ask it to replicate that behavior across other modules

important: always make claude explain what it's doing next

the interface won't let you interrupt and fix things mid-build, so you need to catch issues before they happen

also... if you're not on pro, your credits disappear in like 20 minutes of building

hence all these rules

after a few rounds you'll have something solid

then just make the UI decent... clean font, nice colors, basic UX principles

now you've got a tool you can reuse instead of pasting that same prompt 50 times daily

how to write banger marketing prompts in 3 steps:

forget generic "write marketing copy"... these 3 shifts will change your prompting game

1. engineer impossible roles
stop saying "expert marketer"
instead, create someone who couldn't exist but should

"you're a behavioral economist who accidentally became a copywriter after studying casino psychology for a decade and discovered the exact triggers that make people say yes before thinking"

specificity unlocks creativity the model didn't know it had

2. design the emotional journey
don't just ask for "engaging" copy

map the exact feeling: fear -> relief -> excitement -> urgency

"start with the anxiety of being left behind, shift to hope that change is possible, build excitement about the transformation, end with fear of missing this specific window"

emotion is the entire game

3. give creative room to breathe
constraints are good and micromanagement kills output

set boundaries: "maintain professional tone, focus on these benefits"
then release control: "but surprise me with the approach"

the AI needs space to be creative within your framework

works for everything: ads, emails, landing pages, social content
what's the one life-changing book you'd recommend everyone read?

The idea of manifold optimization. Let's figure it out â¬‡ï¸

A manifold is a curved space/surface that looks flat if you zoom in close enough (e.g. a sphere with all points equidistant from the center)

In AI, manifolds are spaces where data or model parameters exist under specific constraints.

So hereâ€™s what manifold optimization looks like:

â–ªï¸ It constrains model parameters on a specific geometric surface (a manifold) instead of free movement in flat space.
â–ªï¸ This way, the optimizer moves in the tangent space â€“ a small, locally flat area that touches the manifold at the current point.
â–ªï¸ After each step, parameters are corrected with a retraction to restore constraints like unit norm or orthogonality.

As a result, each update stays consistent with the manifoldâ€™s geometry.

This is how it works at the single-layer level.
@thinkymachines scaled this optimization across the entire network with modular manifolds that make it geometry-aware.

Dive into how this mechanism works: https://t.co/272Ml1KnRS

Costs to reproduce:
 - ARC-AGI-1 Public: 9h 52m 6 * 2x8H100 * $8/hourÂ  = $157.86
 - ARC-AGI-1 Semi-private: 11h 23m* 2x8H100 * $8/hourÂ  = $176.38
 - ARC-AGI-1 Public: 9h 35m * 3x8H100 * $8/hourÂ  = $216.58
 - ARC-AGI-2 Semi-private: 10h 30m * 3x8H100 * $8/hourÂ  = $252

Semi private costs *more* than public eval even though there are less tasks because public eval data is included in the semi private run. So semi private includes incremental tasks rather than swapping out sets

Two views of AGI that get mixed and confused: The process of generalization vs the consequence of it

 - As a process: The system that learns and generalizes (ARC-AGI)
 - As a consequence: The results and value that generalization produces (GDPval)

Both are valid instruments for different purposes

Even though I have nits on specifics, in general I'm very supportive of more definitions of intelligence and AGI - so I'm directionally aligned with @DanHendrycks and the work here.

Nice job getting it out.

> Our definition of AGI is an AI that can match or exceed the cognitive versatility and proficiency of a well-educated adult

The key part to this definition is "cognitive versatility" - how well can you adapt to novelty? That is the key measure we need to test

We know you can make AI "proficient" at nearly anything. So adding in a "well-educated" qualifier in this definition is just a matter of training

Imagine your body is a Call of Duty map like Nuketown, and your T cells are your teammates. The match starts, and you guys go out and kill cancerous cells â€” the enemy team â€” but you canâ€™t always see every enemy on the map. Some are hidden behind walls, etc. 

What you need is an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) that highlights every opponent, regardless of where theyâ€™re hiding.

(At least I think this is a good metaphor. Iâ€™m very much not an expert here, which is why Iâ€™m putting it in CoD terms.)

Googleâ€™s C2S-Scale 27B model found a drug that does just that. Itâ€™s a â€œconditional amplifier,â€ meaning it boosts the immune signal. This turns â€œcoldâ€ tumors â€” tumors invisible to the bodyâ€™s immune system â€” â€œhot,â€ so they can be eliminated from the map.

Cancer drugs like this are found by humans all the time. There are something like 600 FDAâ€‘approved drugâ€“cancer indication pairs in the US alone. Whatâ€™s unique about this story is that Google used a large language model as a starting point to work on the discovery process.

They took the open Gemma model, fine-tuned it on biological data, then scaled it up a bunch to make it useful. The discovery is yet another confirmation that scaling laws apply to a wide range of important domains, and that â€œtext is a universal interface,â€ to put it in @roon's parlance.

As cool as this is â€” and to be clear itâ€™s very, very cool â€” itâ€™s not a cure for cancer. The conversion rate from potential cancer treatment to FDA approval is something like 5%. A lot of potential cancer therapies like Googleâ€™s are culled before they even get submitted. So the scoreboard is one discovery for AI vs. thousands for humans, but slope matters way more than y-intercept here.

Biotech markets havenâ€™t reacted strongly to the news. It will be a long time until this technology starts delivering value at scale. But itâ€™s the start of something really, really remarkable. 

It might not be the ChatGPT moment for AI in bio. It feels a little more like the 2005 DARPA Grand Challenge when Sebastian Thrun and his team built â€œStanley,â€ a modified Volkswagen Touareg that won the self-driving competition. Over the next two decades, self-driving became a major focus for Google and eventually rolled out for public use.

There will be many hurdles ahead, but itâ€™s exciting to see a new application for AI firmly in the scaling era.

â€” John

If we were to assign a movie rating to OpenAI, would it be G, PG, PG-13, R, or NC-17?

Yesterday, Instagram announced what seemed like a small change to the content it will make available to teens. But it marked a huge change in how we talk about adult content on these platforms.

For years, big tech has issued statement after statement about trust and safety, putting users first, making content uplifting, etc. All noble goals, but all vague proclamations. The Instagram news is a big deal because the company finally stated its policies in language everyone can understand:

â€œTeen Instagram users by default will be able to access content similar to what they might see in a PG-13 movie.â€

Itâ€™s so obvious, I donâ€™t know how we didnâ€™t adopt this standard earlier.

Weâ€™ve spent years debating free speech and adult content. And at this point, everyone agrees that you canâ€™t shout â€œFire!â€ in a crowded theater when it comes to explicit content â€” but instead, that â€œyouâ€™ll know [explicit content] when you see it.â€ 

But there are other lines we should be able to draw as a functioning society. Tech leaders should be able to articulate these lines clearly with users, parents, advertisers, politicians, and anyone else who wants to know. The MPAA ratings (G, PG, PG-13, R, and NC-17) are lindy. Everyone intuitively feels when content drifts from PG-13 to R territory, and AI can easily make the same types of determinations. Thereâ€™s also a perfect set of training data here: every film ever released in America with an MPAA rating.

Every tech companyâ€™s brand carries a set of user experience expectations. Apple, Microsoft, and Google have always maintained a pretty squeaky clean image. In 2010, Steve Jobs made his stance crystal clear: â€œWe do believe we have a moral responsibility to keep porn off the iPhone. Folks who want porn can buy an Android phone.â€ If you were to give Apple an MPAA rating, it would probably be PG.

Microsoft is so professional that they really donâ€™t run into many issues. They do own Xbox and Call of Duty, but the LinkedIn owner isnâ€™t exactly pushing boundaries. Microsoft feels spiritually G-rated.

Google might earn a PG-13 rating because of YouTube â€” there are videos that arenâ€™t appropriate for kids on there â€” but the company is constantly fighting back against more mature content taking over the platform. You can show off a gun on YouTube, but you canâ€™t run ads on that content, and you also canâ€™t assemble a gun on camera. (Admittedly, Google is a bit messy, given that it provides searches of adult content, but I still think the general vibe of Google is PG-13.)

Metaâ€™s always been an open question as influencers have grown more scantily clad over the years, but it still feels like PG-13 to me.

ð• has always been NC-17, even back when it was Twitter. Adult content has always been allowed, but kept behind appropriate warnings. And the algorithm has always done a good job of keeping adult content out of the broader feed.

The toughest company to assess through the MPAA ratings lens is Amazon. Itâ€™s largely a digital Walmart and cloud hosting company, but they also own Twitch and Kindle Direct Publishing. Twitch has had a crazy string of content moderation crises, but has landed in a place where it very much doesnâ€™t allow adult content. Amazon, however, takes a different approach to written content, allowing text erotica on the platform as long as it doesnâ€™t depict anything illegal or exploitative. In some ways, that makes Amazon one of the most â€˜NC-17-ratedâ€™ company in Big Tech.

Tech companies will inevitably draw their moral lines in slightly different places, and all will evolve over time. What I want is clarity on where each organization sees its ultimate limit. I also want to be able to filter content by MPAA rating â€” just like I want to know that when I take my kids to the movies, it will be showing R-rated films, but none that are NC-17.

The big question today is where OpenAI sits. Since ChatGPTâ€™s launch, the default assumption was that OpenAI would follow Googleâ€™s default content moderation lines. With Sam Altman announcing that OpenAI will begin allowing â€œeroticaâ€ on the platform, it feels like the brand has jumped from PG-13 to NC-17. I have no doubt OpenAI will be able to wall off adult content effectively, but with this news, it feels like thereâ€™s suddenly a XXX theater in the back of your local AMC.

@popovicu94 My entire point here is the premise of giving up on CUDA for learning FPGAs. 

Chip Design is a different ball game. Obviously you have FPGAs, ASICs, RTL, HDL, and everything but they are completely tangentially to a much higher level programming abstraction like CUDA or Triton and the likes
@beaversteever Yeah, that's why I am asking everyone to not listen to your stupid advice.

@swyx @gdb There's a lot of untruthfulness behind this statement.

They had started hiring physical design and DV engineers since 2023. Many chip startups were already in their first or second iterations. If you want someone to change their approach, you need to pay for their first iteration. You can't expect them to invest and change mid way because who's stopping you from doing what Microsoft did with Graphcore.

Please, for the sake of your career don't do this.

FPGAs are no good beyond prototyping and emulation and once you have two generations of hardware deployed only incremental blocks of hardware are ever taken to the FPGA. 

They don't scale, they are slow, and most importantly your skills are not, absolutely not transferrable to ASIC programming at all. 

At least not at the sake of learning CUDA/GPU Programming.

Holy shit... NVIDIA just did the impossible ðŸ¤¯

They trained a 12B-parameter LLM on 10 TRILLION tokens using only 4-bit precision.

It's called NVFP4, and it matches FP8 accuracy while cutting compute and memory costs in HALF.

This isn't incremental improvement. This is a complete paradigm shift.

Here's how they cracked it:

â†’ Random Hadamard transforms to eliminate outliers
â†’ 2D scaling that preserves gradient flow
â†’ Stochastic rounding for unbiased updates
â†’ Selective high-precision layers where it matters

The results are absurd:

Same accuracy as FP8. Half the resources. Record-breaking efficiency.

While everyone's been racing to scale up, NVIDIA just proved you can scale DOWN and still win.

This could redefine how every frontier model gets trained.

The 4-bit era just started.

Readers responded with both surprise and agreement last week when I wrote that the single biggest predictor of how rapidly a team makes progress building an AI agent lay in their ability to drive a disciplined process for evals (measuring the systemâ€™s performance) and error analysis (identifying the causes of errors). Itâ€™s tempting to shortcut these processes and to quickly attempt fixes to mistakes rather than slowing down to identify the root causes. But evals and error analysis can lead to much faster progress. In this first of a two-part letter, Iâ€™ll share some best practices for finding and addressing issues in agentic systems.

Even though error analysis has long been an important part of building supervised learning systems, it is still underappreciated compared to, say, using the latest and buzziest tools. Identifying the root causes of particular kinds of errors might seem â€œboring,â€ but it pays off! If you are not yet persuaded that error analysis is important, permit me to point out:
- To master a composition on a musical instrument, you donâ€™t only play the same piece from start to end. Instead, you identify where youâ€™re stumbling and practice those parts more.
- To be healthy, you donâ€™t just build your diet around the latest nutrition fads. You also ask your doctor about your bloodwork to see if anything is amiss. (I did this last month and am happy to report Iâ€™m in good health! ðŸ˜ƒ)
- To improve your sports teamâ€™s performance, you donâ€™t just practice trick shots. Instead, you review game films to spot gaps and then address them.

To improve your agentic AI system, donâ€™t just stack up the latest buzzy techniques that just went viral on social media (though I find it fun to experiment with buzzy AI techniques as much as the next person!). Instead, use error analysis to figure out where itâ€™s falling short, and focus on that.

Before analyzing errors, we first have to decide what is an error. So the first step is to put in evals. Iâ€™ll focus on that for the remainder of this letter and discuss error analysis next week.

If you are using supervised learning to train a binary classifier, the number of ways the algorithm could make a mistake is limited. It could output 0 instead of 1, or vice versa. There is also a handful of standard metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, F1, ROC, etc. that apply to many problems. So as long as you know the test distribution, evals are relatively straightforward, and much of the work of error analysis lies in identifying what types of input an algorithm fails on, which also leads to data-centric AI techniques for acquiring more data to augment the algorithm in areas where itâ€™s weak.

With generative AI, a lot of intuitions from evals and error analysis of supervised learning carry over â€” history doesnâ€™t repeat itself, but it rhymes â€” and developers who are already familiar with machine learning and deep learning often adapt to generative AI faster than people who are starting from scratch. But one new challenge is that the space of outputs is much richer, so there are many more ways an algorithmâ€™s output might be wrong.

Take the example of automated processing of financial invoices where we use an agentic workflow to populate a financial database with information from received invoices. Will the algorithm incorrectly extract the invoice due date? Or the final amount? Or mistake the payer address for the biller address? Or get the financial currency wrong? Or make the wrong API call so the verification process fails? Because the output space is much larger, the number of failure modes is also much larger.

Rather than defining an error metric ahead of time, it is therefore typically more effective to first quickly build a prototype, then manually examine a handful of agent outputs to see where it performs well and where it stumbles. This allows you to focus on building datasets and error metrics â€” sometimes objective metrics implemented in code, and sometimes subjective metrics using LLM-as-judge â€” to check the systemâ€™s  performance in the dimensions you are most concerned about. In supervised learning, we sometimes tune the error metric to better reflect what humans care about. With agentic workflows, I find tuning evals to be even more iterative, with more frequent tweaks to the evals to capture the wider range of things that can go wrong.

I discuss this and other best practices in detail in Module 4 of the Agentic AI course on https://t.co/zGHUh1loPO that we announced last week. After building evals, you now have a measurement of your systemâ€™s performance, which provides a foundation for trying different modifications to your agent, as you can now measure what makes a difference. The next step is then to perform error analysis to pinpoint what changes to focus your development efforts on. Iâ€™ll discuss this further next week.

Learn to build your own voice-activated AI assistant that can execute tasks like gathering recent AI news from the web, scripting out a podcast, and using tools to put all that into a multi-speaker podcast. See our new short course: "Building Live Voice Agents with Googleâ€™s ADK (Agent Development Kit),â€  taught by Googleâ€™s @lavinigam and @sitalakshmi_s.

ADK provides modular components that make it easy to build and debug agents. It also includes a built-in web interface for tracing agentic reasoning. This course illustrates these concepts via  building a live voice agent that can chain actions to complete a complex task like creating a podcast. This requires maintaining context, implementing guardrails, reasoning, and handling audio streaming, while keeping latency low.

Youâ€™ll learn to:
- Build voice agents that listen, reason, and respond
- Guide your agent to follow a specific workflow to accomplish a task
- Coordinate specialized agents to build an agentic podcast workflow that researches topics and produces multi-speaker audio
- Understand how to deploy an agent into production

Knowledge of how the real world works is a torment.

Ask @BrianRoemmele. 

He has hundreds of such stories of enterprise incompetence like this. @businessbarista nails the structural problems. I'm working with another company about this size and same issue. It's why I hate committees so deeply after working inside Microsoft years ago. So many stories of innovation failures it's amazing anyone changes. 

But they do, and will. It sure would be easier if everyone got on board faster. But they won't, and don't. In fact, most will call us idiots for even trying.

Even smart leaders can't change due to new information that quickly. Reminds me of sitting next to @timoreilly at Google's first advertiser's conference. He told me all about Web 2.0 the day after he wrote the famous Web 2.0 blog/memo. I wrote it all up for Bill Gates and the answer that came back was my ideas had no business value. Later he bought Skype for $6 billion more than if he had listened.

We are still in these early days of change. We talked about digital transformation for decades. We will see AI transformation inside big enterprises for at least as long.

Next week I'll be talking with many of the enterprise people about robots at @rwang0's conference. And warn them again that they need to change faster. 

But they won't. They can't.

We'll get cheers. We'll get accolades at lunch. Then everyone will go back to their big companies and all the life will be drained from their big ideas. 

The successful ones will do cultural change initiatives before the robots arrive. But only the best will do that. So few will.

This is the torment of being old in this industry. They call us "the grey beards." We know how hard it is to get everyone moving in a new direction. 

This knowledge gives me nightmares.
